title: Ada Lovelace publishes the first computer program
description: Ada Augusta, Countess of Lovelace, publishes an algorithm for computing the Numbers of Bernoulli using the theoretical Analytical Engine of Charles Babbage. It's source code, and it was openly published.

title: Software shared as public domain
description: While not called "open source" at the time, researchers would collaborate on code and considered it communal knowledge

title: ARPANET is created
description: Created in 1969 and shut down in 1990, the Advanced Research Projects Agency Network (ARPANET) was a network project that the United States agency ARPA (later known as DARPA) funded in 1966 with the goal of enabling communication and access to remote systems. An additional goal of ARPANET was to facilitate the distribution of software. ARPANET initially implemented the 1822 protocol, then switched to the Network Control Protocol (NCP), before transitioning to TCP/IP. ARPANET is generally considered to be one of the predecessors to the Internet.

title: Commission on New Technological Uses of Copyrighted Works recommended that software should be protected by copyright law
description: The Commission on New Technological Uses of Copyrighted Works (or CONTU) was a three-year study on copyright in regards to computers and "machine duplication systems", with the goal of revising copyright laws in the United States. CONTU recommended that software be subject to copyright, with one dissention expressing that an executable program itself should not be copyrightable as it counts as a "machine-control element". The Computer Software Copyright Act of 1980 implemented much of CONTU's recommendations.

title: Software and modifications are shared via Usenet, BBS networks, et al.
description: In the 1980s, users distributed software and source code to others on Usenet, online bulletin board systems (BBS), and other communities. While some of the software was distributed just so that it could be used, the 1980s also saw users modifying the software and subsequently sharing their modifications. Communities to discuss and collaborate on modifications emerged.

title: Software copyright rises to the status of literary works
description: In the case of Apple Computer, Inc. v. Franklin Computer Corporation, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit ruled that computer software could be protected by copyright. This effectively put a halt to "public domain" software and propelled proprietary software as a lucrative business model.

title: The MIT license is released
description: After the establishment of software's copyrightability in the United States, researchers at the Computer Systems Research (CSR) group at MIT saw the need to place conditions around the distribution of network software that they had developed. As the goal of sharing the software was to steer the direction of technology, not to sell it, they drafted some initial text that added a permission notice to a copyright notice. This became known as the MIT License.

title: The first version of the GPL is released
description: In 1989, Richard Stallman created the GNU General Public License (GPL) in response to the commercialization of code that had previously been freely available. Stallman was forced to remove this now-proprietary code from GNU Emacs. The GPL aimed to codify the rights and obligations of free software.

title: The first BSD-style license is released
description: While the first definitive 4-clause BSD license was published in 1990, its roots are present in its predecessor which accompanied the BSD-authored networking code included in 4.3BSD-Tahoe. This license primarily required that copyright notices be maintained and that products that redistributed it attribute the University of California et al. The first BSD License to conform to the open source definition (OSD) was the 3-clause license, sometimes referred to as "BSD-new", which was published in 1999.

title: Linux is released
description: Linux started as a toy project of Linus Torvalds, who wanted an operating system that would could run on Intel's 80386 x86 microprocessor and was freely available, modifiable, and redistributable. He first posted about the project on the MINIX Usenet newsgroup. Linus released the 0.01 version of Linux with bash and gcc under his own license that restricted the use of it from commercial use.

title: Red Hat Inc. is founded
description: Founded by Bob Young and Marc Ewing, Red Hat Inc.brought a stable and secure distribution of Linux to businesses. By conforming to software development practices such as regular and predictable release cadences, it positioned itself as a viable alternative to less open operating systems, such as Microsoft.

title: The Apache HTTP Server is released
description: After the development of NCSA HTTPd had come to a standstill, a group of developers collaborated on what became known as the Apache HTTP Server which was based on NCSA HTTPd. The Apache HTTP Server quickly became the most popular server on the Internet, and contributed to the growth of the early World Wide Web. This software was the first to be released under the Apache Software License.

title: The term "open source" is coined
description: After Netscape announced that it would be releasing the source code for Navigator, a group of technologists held a strategy session in Palo Alto, California. During this session, Christine Peterson, proposed the term "open source software" to differentiate software that was freely available to modify from cost-free to use.

title: The Apache Software Foundation is formed
description: The Apache Software Foundation (ASF) was initially formed as a charitable nonprofit in 1999 by the group of people working on the Apache HTTP Server. The ASF's mission is "to provide software for the public good". It hosts a wide variety of open source projects and provides infrastructure, frameworks, and guidance for their development.

title: The Linux Foundation is formed
description: The Linux Foundation (LF) was formed as a nonprofit business league in 2000, initially to support the development of Linux. It has expanded its scope to include other projects and directed funds, such as the Cloud Native Computing Foundation and the OpenJS Foundation. The LF's mission is to provide "a neutral, trusted hub for developers to code, manage, and scale open technology projects".

title: Git is released
description: Many Linux kernel developers had been using BitKeeper as their source control management system, but in 2005 BitKeeper removed its free version, without which they were motivated to create Git as a replacement. Their requirements for Git included that it support distributed workflows, operate quickly, be able to work for large projects (like Linux), and maintain simplicity in its design. Led initially by Linus Torvalds, Junio Hamano became the core maintainer in July of 2005.
